concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm glad you're here today. Feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for having me. I'm just feeling really stressed about my future, especially about finding a stable path to stay in the US.
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling a lot of uncertainty and pressure about your future and securing stability. What about this situation is weighing most heavily on you right now?
client: I think it's the feeling that I don't have enough time to sort everything out. It's overwhelming trying to figure out grad school and job stability all at once.

It sounds like a lot is on your plate, and itâ€™s understandable to feel overwhelmed with so much happening at once. What do you imagine your life might look like if you were to find that stability and clarity you're seeking?

I think it would feel like a huge weight lifted off my shoulders. I'd be more relaxed, knowing that I'm on a clear path and not constantly worried about having to leave the US or being stuck in limbo.
That sounds like a peaceful and fulfilling vision for your future. What are some small steps you think you might take towards achieving that clarity and stability?

client: Maybe starting by researching more grad programs that might accept my background or looking into possible job options that align with my skills. I could also talk to people in the field to get some advice.

It sounds like you have some clear ideas for moving forward, and those are great steps. Based on what you said, possible options include dedicating specific time each week to research grad programs and job options, and setting up informational interviews with professionals in your field. What do you think might be a good first step for you, and how can you anticipate and overcome any challenges you might face?

I think starting with research would be a good idea, just to get a clearer picture of what's out there. The challenge is staying motivated and not getting discouraged if I don't find options right away, so maybe setting small goals or timelines could help.

It's wonderful that you're considering starting with research, and setting small goals or timelines sounds like a practical strategy to maintain motivation. How about creating a plan where you dedicate a set amount of time each week to this research and define specific goals for what you hope to achieve within that period? What do you think could help you stay on track, and how might you monitor your progress?

I like the idea of dedicating a specific time each week to focus on research, and maybe using a planner or an app to keep track of my goals and progress. Checking in with myself weekly to see what I've accomplished could also help me stay on track and motivated.

You've put together a thoughtful plan to tackle these challenges one step at a time, and that's truly commendable. Dedicating time each week for research and using a planner or app to track your goals are effective strategies to stay organized and focused. Checking in with yourself weekly will help keep your motivation alive and provide a sense of accomplishment.

Remember, taking these small steps is progress in itself, and every little bit counts towards creating the future you envision. Stay compassionate with yourself through this journey. You're doing great work, and I'm confident you can navigate this path successfully. Until our next session, keep leaning on your strengths and celebrating each small victory.
Thanks, I appreciate it. I'll try to keep the momentum going and see how far I get. I'll let you know how it goes next time.
